prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The IRAM and APEX peak temperatures of 8 and 5.3 mK main-beam temperatures in the 2-1 and 3-2 line have been converted to flux taking into account that the source size and beam size are comparable (following http://safe.nrao.edu/wiki/pub/Main/RadioTutorial/flux-to-brightness.pdf). The result is 60 and 180 mJy respectively.
Alternatively, the rms noise obtained in the IRAM and APEX data are equivalent to 11 and 22 mJy at a channel spacing of 1.6 and 2.1 km/s, respectively. To determine the line shape unequivocally, in particular to say with confidence if there is a spike located at the velocity of the star, we aim for a better velocity reolution of 0.4-0.6 km/s. In addition the S/N should be at least a factor 3 better than shown in Figure 1. This results in a requested sensitivity of 5 and 10 mJy in the 2-1 and 3-2 line at the requested spectral resolution.

In band 6, one spectral window is placed on the CO(2-1) line (230.5 GHz) while the other three are placed (213.0, 215.0, and 228.0 GHz) such as to obtain an estimate of the dust continuum (no line is expected to be strong enough to show up). Of the available correlator modes, the one with a resolution of 488 KHz (or 0.64 km/s) matches the expected outflow velocities of 10-15 km/s.
The velocity resolution in the continuum subbands has been reduced. If the enveloppe is indeed smaller than predicted by the photodissociation radius as suggested by the IRAM data than the continuum data will provide important additional constraints to the dust modelling.
Similarly, in band 7 the spectral windows are placed at 345.8 GHz (CO J=3-2) and 333.0, 335.0, and 347.0 GHz to estimate the continuum flux. The 488 KHz resolution mode corresponds to 0.42 km/s and we may even smooth the spectrum on the CO(3-2) line in order to match the 0.64 km/s resolution in the J=2-1 line, and to improve the S/N.

The IRAM observations suggested that the source is smaller than IRAM beam size at 230 GHz of 11", so that a single pointing is sufficient.
Since any possible disk component is supposed to contribute little to the flux we do not aim for very high spatial resolution (0.5-1" as suggested in Bujarrabal et al. 2013). A resolution of 0.8" is aimed for, which is sufficient to conclusively determine the size of the outflow.
We have used the ALMA Observation Support Tool (OST) on a point-source and a slightly-extended source (the "W49-like Star Formation region in dwarf galaxy Leo T" template) to simulate the observations, and verified that the uv-coverage is excellent even for the relatively short integration times (7-10 minutes) in the J=2-1 line.
The technical justification for the 3-2 line is included in the one for the 2-1 line.
The technical justification for the 3-2 line is included in the one for the 2-1 line.
The technical justification for the 3-2 line is included in the one for the 2-1 line.

Based on the value of (Mass-loss rate/distance-squared) one expects peak fluxes that are about a factor of 3 lower than for HIP 53449, or about 20 and 60 mJy at 230 and 345 GHz, respectively. The requested sensitivities are adjusted to reach S/N levels that are slightly lower (about 15) than that for HIP 53449 but would still allow for a convincing detection and line shape analysis.

In band 6, one spectral window is placed on the CO(2-1) line (230.5 GHz) while the other three are placed (213.0, 215.0, and 228.0 GHz) such as to obtain an estimate of the dust continuum (no line is expected to be strong enough to show up). Of the available correlator modes, the one with a resolution of 488 KHz (or 0.64 km/s) matches the expected outflow velocities of 10-15 km/s.
The velocity resolution in the continuum subbands has been reduced. If the enveloppe is indeed smaller than predicted by the photodissociation radius as suggested by the IRAM data than the continuum data will provide important additional constraints to the dust modelling.
Similarly, in band 7 the spectral windows are placed at 345.8 GHz (CO J=3-2) and 333.0, 335.0, and 347.0 GHz to estimate the continuum flux. The 488 KHz resolution mode corresponds to 0.42 km/s and we may even smooth the spectrum on the CO(3-2) line in order to match the 0.64 km/s resolution in the J=2-1 line, and to improve the S/N.

The IRAM observations for HIP 53449 suggested that the source is smaller than IRAM beam size at 230 GHz of 11", so that a single pointing is sufficient.
Since any possible disk component is supposed to contribute little to the flux we do not aim for very high spatial resolution (0.5-1" as suggested in Bujarrabal et al. 2013). A resolution of 0.8" is aimed for, which is sufficient to conclusively determine the size of the outflow.
We have used the ALMA Observation Support Tool (OST) on a point-source and a slightly-extended source (the "W49-like Star Formation region in dwarf galaxy Leo T" template) to simulate the observations, and verified that the uv-coverage is excellent even for the relatively short integration times (7-10 minutes) in the J=2-1 line.
The technical justification for the 2-1 line is included in the one for the 3-2 line.
The technical justification for the 2-1 line is included in the one for the 3-2 line.
The technical justification for the 2-1 line is included in the one for the 3-2 line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
For stars with initial masses below about 1 Msol, mass loss on the first red giant branch (RGB) dominates that of the later AGB phase. Nevertheless, RGB mass loss is often parameterised by a simple Reimers law in evolution models.
Groenewegen showed that mass loss exists in nearby RGB stars from modelling the SEDs. As follow-up, 5 stars were observed with IRAM and APEX. HIP 53449 was detected in the CO 2-1 line (and marginally in the J=3-2 line), the object with the largest mass-loss rate based on the previous analysis of the SED. The shape of the line profiles is intruiging. The expansion velocity is unexpectedly large, and there is a hint for a rotating disk. The comparison to a line emission code suggests that the CO envelope is significantly smaller than follows from the photodissociation radius.
It is proposed to observe HIP53449, and the star with the next largest detection probability HIP 67665, in the CO 2-1 and 3-2 lines. The observations will unequivocally determine the line profiles. More importantly the spatial resolution of ALMA will allow to determine the size of the CO shell and show if it is indeed much smaller than the standard photodissociation radius.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is a resubmission of proposal 2013.1.00251.S that was ranked in the top 10% of all proposals. Only 1 of 4 SBs has been executed. The results are puzzling and we request a completion of the project. To improve on a S/N and get a completely independent measurement to confirm the result, we do request to reobserve the J=3-2 line. This will cost only 0.5h
